what: Q: How many indicators does localintel support?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: package ships curated registries 14 domains. can also use process_eurostat() process Eurostat dataset registry.
code: n <- indicator_count() cat(n$indicators, "indicators across", n$domains, "domains\n") print(n$by_domain)

what: Q: My dataset isn’t in the registry. Can I still use localintel?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: Absolutely. core pipeline (fetch → process → cascade → visualize → export) works Eurostat dataset. Use generic workflow:
code: library(dplyr)  raw <- get_nuts_level_robust("your_eurostat_code", level = 2, years = 2010:2024)  processed <- process_eurostat(raw,   filters = list(unit = "PC", sex = "T"),   out_col = "my_indicator")  cascaded <- cascade_to_nuts2(   processed, vars = "my_indicator", years = 2010:2024)

what: Q: The Eurostat API is returning empty data or timing out.
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: Eurostat bulk download API can intermittent. localintel built-mitigation: problems persist, clear Eurostat cache:
code: data <- get_nuts_level_robust("nama_10r_2gdp", level = 2, years = 2010:2024) data <- get_nuts_level_safe("nama_10r_2gdp", level = 2, years = 2010:2024) eurostat::clean_eurostat_cache()

what: Q: How can I speed up repeated runs?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: Save fetched data locally:
code: data_list <- fetch_eurostat_batch(economy_codes(), level = 2, years = 2010:2024) export_to_rds(data_list, "data/raw_economy.rds")  # Later data_list <- readRDS("data/raw_economy.rds")

what: Q: How does cascading decide which level to use?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: Priority order: NUTS 2 > NUTS 1 > NUTS 0. src_<variable>_level column tracks level value came .

what: Q: Should I use cascade_to_nuts2() or cascade_to_nuts2_and_compute()?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: Use cascade_to_nuts2() domain — fully generic. Use cascade_to_nuts2_and_compute() need health-specific derived indicators (DA rLOS).

what: Q: Why do some countries appear as a single block on the map?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: country reports NUTS 0, map uses national boundary. design — “best available resolution” approach.

what: Q: Can I use ggplot2 instead of tmap?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
text: Yes. Build sf object build_display_sf(), plot ggplot2:
code: library(ggplot2) sf_data <- build_display_sf(cascaded, geopolys, var = "gdp", years = 2023:2023) ggplot(sf_data) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = value), color = "white", size = 0.1) +   scale_fill_viridis_c() +   theme_minimal()

what: Q: Which EU countries are included?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
code: eu27_codes() filtered <- keep_eu27(data, extras = c("NO", "CH"))

what: Q: How do I cite localintel?
title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
code: @software{localintel,   author = {Htitich, Mohamed},   title = {localintel: Local Intelligence for Subnational Data Analysis},   year = {2025},   url = {https://github.com/MohamedHtitich1/localintel} }

title: Getting Started with localintel
text: localintel (Local Intelligence) R package provides unified pipeline 150+ subnational indicators across 14 thematic domains Eurostat. regional dataset — economy, health, education, labour, demographics, tourism, transport, environment, — can fetched, harmonized, cascaded NUTS 2, scored, mapped, exported single consistent workflow.

title: Getting Started with localintel
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("MohamedHtitich1/localintel") library(localintel)

title: Getting Started with localintel
text: localintel ships curated code lists 14 Eurostat domains:
code: # How many indicators are available? n <- indicator_count() cat(n$indicators, "indicators across", n$domains, "domains\n") print(n$by_domain)  # View codes for a specific domain economy_codes() labour_codes() education_codes()

title: Getting Started with localintel
text: Use fetch_eurostat_batch() download multiple datasets : individual datasets control:
code: # Fetch economy indicators at NUTS2 level econ_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(economy_codes(), level = 2, years = 2015:2024) econ_data <- drop_empty(econ_data)  # Fetch health indicators hlth_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(health_system_codes(), level = 2, years = 2015:2024) hlth_data <- drop_empty(hlth_data)  # Fetch labour indicators lab_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(labour_codes(), level = 2, years = 2015:2024) lab_data <- drop_empty(lab_data) gdp_raw <- get_nuts_level_robust("nama_10r_2gdp", level = 2, years = 2015:2024)

title: Getting Started with localintel
text: Use domain-specific processors universal process_eurostat(): Combine processed datasets:
code: # Domain-specific processors gdp       <- process_gdp(econ_data$gdp_nuts2) beds      <- process_beds(hlth_data$beds) unemp     <- process_unemployment_rate(lab_data$unemployment_rate)  # Or the generic processor for any dataset life_exp <- process_eurostat(   get_nuts_level_robust("demo_r_mlifexp", level = 2, years = 2015:2024),   filters = list(sex = "T", age = "Y_LT1"),   out_col = "life_expectancy" ) all_data <- merge_datasets(gdp, beds, unemp, life_exp)

title: Getting Started with localintel
text: every region reports NUTS 2. cascade fills gaps parent levels:
code: nuts2_ref <- get_nuts2_ref()  cascaded <- cascade_to_nuts2(   all_data,   vars = c("gdp", "beds", "unemployment_rate", "life_expectancy"),   nuts2_ref = nuts2_ref,   years = 2015:2024 )  # Check source levels — how much data was cascaded? table(cascaded$src_gdp_level)

title: Getting Started with localintel
code: geopolys <- get_nuts_geopolys()  plot_best_by_country_level(   cascaded, geopolys,   var = "unemployment_rate",   years = 2022:2024,   title = "Unemployment Rate (%)",   scale = "global" )

title: Getting Started with localintel
code: # Single variable sf_data <- build_display_sf(cascaded, geopolys, var = "gdp", years = 2015:2024) export_to_geojson(sf_data, "output/gdp_nuts2.geojson")  # Multi-variable with labels and domain grouping sf_all <- build_multi_var_sf(   cascaded, geopolys,   vars = c("gdp", "beds", "unemployment_rate", "life_expectancy"),   years = 2015:2024,   var_labels = regional_var_labels(),   pillar_mapping = regional_domain_mapping() )  sf_enriched <- enrich_for_tableau(sf_all, get_population_nuts2(), get_nuts2_names()) export_to_geojson(sf_enriched, "output/multi_domain_dashboard.geojson")

title: Getting Started with localintel
text: localintel works full Eurostat regional statistics catalogue. Use all_regional_codes() complete list, domain-specific functions like economy_codes(), education_codes(), tourism_codes(), etc.

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: library(localintel) library(dplyr)

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
text: Eurostat organizes subnational statistics using NUTS classification: NUTS 0 — Country level (e.g., DE Germany) NUTS 1 — Major socio-economic regions (e.g., DE1 Baden-Württemberg) NUTS 2 — Basic regions (e.g., DE11 Stuttgart) countries report NUTS 2. localintel handles data cascading (Phase 3).

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: n <- indicator_count() cat(n$indicators, "indicators across", n$domains, "domains\n") print(n$by_domain)

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: # Economy econ_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(economy_codes(), level = 2, years = 2010:2024)  # Labour market lab_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(labour_codes(), level = 2, years = 2010:2024)  # Health hlth_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(health_system_codes(), level = 2, years = 2010:2024)  # Education educ_data <- fetch_eurostat_batch(education_codes(), level = 2, years = 2010:2024)  # Drop any empty results econ_data <- drop_empty(econ_data) lab_data  <- drop_empty(lab_data) hlth_data <- drop_empty(hlth_data) educ_data <- drop_empty(educ_data)

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
text: domain convenience processors filter right dimensions:
code: # Economy gdp           <- process_gdp(econ_data$gdp_nuts2)  # Labour unemp         <- process_unemployment_rate(lab_data$unemployment_rate) empl_rate     <- process_eurostat(lab_data$employment_rate,                    filters = list(sex = "T", age = "Y20-64"),                    out_col = "employment_rate")  # Health beds          <- process_beds(hlth_data$beds) physicians    <- process_physicians(hlth_data$physicians)  # Education tertiary      <- process_education_attainment(educ_data$attain_tertiary)

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
text: datasets without dedicated processor, use process_eurostat():
code: # Tourism: nights spent nights_raw <- get_nuts_level_robust("tour_occ_nin2", level = 2, years = 2010:2024) nights     <- process_eurostat(nights_raw,   filters = list(unit = "NR", nace_r2 = "I551-I553", c_resid = "TOTAL"),   out_col = "nights_spent")  # R&D expenditure rd_raw <- get_nuts_level_robust("rd_e_gerdreg", level = 2, years = 2010:2024) rd     <- process_eurostat(rd_raw,   filters = list(unit = "PC_GDP", sectperf = "TOTAL"),   out_col = "rd_expenditure")

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
text: Combine indicators one table:
code: all_data <- merge_datasets(gdp, unemp, empl_rate, beds, physicians, tertiary) glimpse(all_data)

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: nuts2_ref <- get_nuts2_ref() geopolys  <- get_nuts_geopolys()

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: cascaded <- cascade_to_nuts2(   all_data,   vars = c("gdp", "unemployment_rate", "employment_rate",            "beds", "physicians", "education_attainment"),   nuts2_ref = nuts2_ref,   years = 2010:2024 )  # Check coverage cascaded %>%   summarise(across(starts_with("src_"), ~sum(!is.na(.)))) %>%   glimpse()

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
text: health indicators, specialized cascade also computes derived indicators:
code: cascaded_health <- cascade_to_nuts2_and_compute(   all_data,   vars = c("disch_inp", "disch_day", "beds", "physicians", "los"),   nuts2_ref = nuts2_ref,   years = 2010:2024 )

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: scored <- cascaded %>%   keep_eu27() %>%   transform_and_score(list(     unemp_tr = "-unemployment_rate",     gdp_tr   = "safe_log10(gdp)",     beds_tr  = "beds",     educ_tr  = "education_attainment"   ))

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: plot_best_by_country_level(   cascaded, geopolys,   var = "unemployment_rate",   years = 2022:2024,   title = "Unemployment Rate (%)",   scale = "global" )  plot_best_by_country_level(   cascaded, geopolys,   var = "gdp",   years = 2022:2024,   title = "GDP (million EUR)" )

title: Multi-Domain Regional Analysis
code: sf_all <- build_multi_var_sf(   cascaded, geopolys,   vars = c("gdp", "unemployment_rate", "beds", "education_attainment"),   years = 2010:2024,   var_labels = regional_var_labels(),   pillar_mapping = regional_domain_mapping() )  pop_data    <- get_population_nuts2() nuts2_names <- get_nuts2_names() sf_enriched <- enrich_for_tableau(sf_all, pop_data, nuts2_names)  export_to_geojson(sf_enriched, "output/multi_domain_dashboard.geojson") export_to_excel(cascaded, "output/cascaded_multi_domain.xlsx")

title: localintel – 150+ Subnational Indicators from Eurostat
text: localintel (Local Intelligence) R package provides unified pipeline 150+ subnational indicators across 14 thematic domains Eurostat. Eurostat regional dataset — economy, health, education, labour, demographics, tourism, transport, environment, — can fetched, harmonized, cascaded NUTS 2, scored, mapped, exported single consistent workflow.

title: localintel – 150+ Subnational Indicators from Eurostat
text: See localintel action — mhtitich.com/subnational interactive dashboard built entirely data processed package. maps regional disparities across 235 European NUTS-2 regions 2010–2024, live indicator switching, animated timeline playback, AI-generated regional insights. pipeline fully parametrizable can adapted indicator domain. Interested custom deployment? Get touch.

title: localintel – 150+ Subnational Indicators from Eurostat
code: # Install from GitHub # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("MohamedHtitich1/localintel")

title: localintel – 150+ Subnational Indicators from Eurostat
code: library(localintel)  # See the full indicator registry n <- indicator_count() cat(n$indicators, "indicators across", n$domains, "domains\n")  # 1. Fetch data from multiple domains econ  <- fetch_eurostat_batch(economy_codes(), level = 2, years = 2015:2024) hlth  <- fetch_eurostat_batch(health_system_codes(), level = 2, years = 2015:2024) lab   <- fetch_eurostat_batch(labour_codes(), level = 2, years = 2015:2024)  # 2. Process with domain-specific or generic processors gdp       <- process_gdp(econ$gdp_nuts2) beds      <- process_beds(hlth$beds) unemp     <- process_unemployment_rate(lab$unemployment_rate)  # 3. Merge, cascade to NUTS2, and impute temporal gaps all_data <- merge_datasets(gdp, beds, unemp) cascaded <- cascade_to_nuts2(   all_data,   vars = c("gdp", "beds", "unemployment_rate"),   years = 2015:2024,   impute = TRUE,        # adaptive econometric imputation (PCHIP + ETS)   forecast_to = 2025    # extend series with AIC-selected forecasts )  # Check traceability table(cascaded$src_gdp_level)  # 2=NUTS2, 1=NUTS1, 0=NUTS0 table(cascaded$imp_gdp_flag)   # 0=observed, 1=interpolated, 2=forecasted  # 4. Visualize geopolys <- get_nuts_geopolys() plot_best_by_country_level(cascaded, geopolys, var = "gdp", years = 2022:2024)  # 5. Export for Tableau sf_all <- build_multi_var_sf(   cascaded, geopolys,   vars = c("gdp", "beds", "unemployment_rate"),   years = 2015:2024,   var_labels = regional_var_labels(),   pillar_mapping = regional_domain_mapping() ) export_to_geojson(sf_all, "output/multi_domain_nuts2.geojson")

title: localintel – 150+ Subnational Indicators from Eurostat

title: localintel – 150+ Subnational Indicators from Eurostat
text: package automatically fills missing regional data cascading parent NUTS levels: Every cascaded value tracked via src_<variable>_level columns (2 = original NUTS 2, 1 = NUTS 1, 0 = NUTS 0), enabling full transparency sensitivity analysis.
code: NUTS 0 (Country) → NUTS 1 (Major Regions) → NUTS 2 (Regions)

code: plot_best_by_country_level(cascaded, geopolys, var = "unemployment_rate",   years = 2022:2024, title = "Unemployment Rate (%)", scale = "global")

code: build_display_sf(out_nuts2, geopolys, var, years = NULL,    skip_nuts0 = TRUE, scale = c("per_year", "global")) lc_build_display_sf(out_nuts2, geopolys, var, years = NULL,    skip_nuts0 = TRUE, scale = c("per_year", "global"), keep = NULL) plot_best_by_country_level(out_nuts2, geopolys, var, years = NULL,    skip_nuts0 = TRUE, scale = c("per_year", "global"), title = NULL,    pdf_file = paste0("Map_", var, "_country_level_scaled.pdf"),    bb_x = c(2400000, 7800000), bb_y = c(1320000, 5650000),    col_var = NULL, n_breaks = 7, breaks = NULL) build_multi_var_sf(out_nuts2, geopolys, vars, years = 2010:2024,    var_labels = NULL, pillar_mapping = NULL) level_col_for(var, special_cases = NULL) level_cols_for(vars)

what: Cascade Data to NUTS2 (Generic / Domain-Agnostic) — cascade_to_nuts2
title: Cascade Data to NUTS2 (Generic / Domain-Agnostic) — cascade_to_nuts2
text: Cascades data NUTS0/NUTS1 NUTS2 level set variables thematic domain. Unlike cascade_to_nuts2_and_compute(), function performs pure cascading without computing domain-specific derived indicators, making suitable economy, education, labour, environment, Eurostat domain.

title: Cascade Data to NUTS2 (Generic / Domain-Agnostic) — cascade_to_nuts2
code: cascade_to_nuts2(data, vars, years = NULL, nuts2_ref = NULL, nuts_year = 2024)

title: Cascade Data to NUTS2 (Generic / Domain-Agnostic) — cascade_to_nuts2
text: data Dataframe 'geo', 'year', variable columns. May contain data mixed NUTS levels (identified geo code length: 2=NUTS0, 3=NUTS1, 4=NUTS2). vars Character vector variable names cascade years Integer vector years include. NULL, uses available years. nuts2_ref Reference table get_nuts2_ref(). NULL, fetched automatically. nuts_year Integer year NUTS classification (default: 2024)

title: Cascade Data to NUTS2 (Generic / Domain-Agnostic) — cascade_to_nuts2
text: Dataframe cascaded values NUTS2 level. variable v, corresponding src_v_level column tracks source NUTS level (2 = original NUTS2, 1 = cascaded NUTS1, 0 = cascaded NUTS0).

what: Autoregressive Forecast for Future Observations — forecast_autoregressive
title: Autoregressive Forecast for Future Observations — forecast_autoregressive
text: Applies exponential smoothing state space model (ETS) forecasting beyond last observed value. method autoregressive automatically selects optimal smoothing parameters via ets. Falls back Holt's linear trend extrapolation forecast package unavailable. NA values input series first interpolated using interp_pchip_flag.

title: Autoregressive Forecast for Future Observations — forecast_autoregressive
code: forecast_autoregressive(y, h = 3, method = "ets")

title: Autoregressive Forecast for Future Observations — forecast_autoregressive
text: y Numeric vector observed values (may contain NAs interpolated first) h Integer number periods forecast (default: 3) method Character string: "ets" (default) exponential smoothing via forecast package, "holt_linear" manual Holt's linear trend fallback

title: Autoregressive Forecast for Future Observations — forecast_autoregressive
text: List four components: forecast Numeric vector length h point forecasts lower Numeric vector length h lower 80% confidence interval bounds upper Numeric vector length h upper 80% confidence interval bounds method Character string indicating method used

title: Autoregressive Forecast for Future Observations — forecast_autoregressive
text: method = "ets", function attempts use ets fit exponential smoothing model automatically selected components (error, trend, seasonal). forecast package available, falls back Holt's linear trend method. Holt's linear trend method fits y_t = l_t + t_t l_t level t_t trend, using standard smoothing parameters (alpha = 0.3, beta = 0.1).

what: PCHIP Interpolation with Constant Endpoints — interp_pchip_flag
title: PCHIP Interpolation with Constant Endpoints — interp_pchip_flag
text: Performs Piecewise Cubic Hermite Interpolating Polynomial (PCHIP) interpolation missing values within observed range. Uses monotone Hermite splines (Fritsch-Carlson method) via splinefun robust non-linear patterns avoid overshooting knots. Endpoints beyond observed data held constant (last observation carried forward/backward). function replaces previous linear interpolation approach sophisticated method preserves monotonicity handles non-linear relationships better.

title: PCHIP Interpolation with Constant Endpoints — interp_pchip_flag
code: interp_pchip_flag(y)

text: y Numeric vector interpolate (may contain NAs)

title: PCHIP Interpolation with Constant Endpoints — interp_pchip_flag
text: List two components: value Numeric vector interpolated values; NA positions beyond     range observed data kept constant using nearest observed endpoint flag Integer vector (0/1) indicating values originally NA

title: localintel 0.2.1
text: cascade_to_nuts2() now accepts impute = TRUE (default) forecast_to parameters. cascading, region’s time series automatically filled using PCHIP interpolation (internal gaps) optionally ETS forecasting (future periods, best model selected via AIC). New imp_{variable}_flag columns track imputation method per value: 0 = observed/cascaded, 1 = PCHIP interpolated, 2 = ETS forecasted. existing src_{variable}_level columns preserved cascade source tracking. Set impute = FALSE legacy behaviour (gap-filling). geometry reference functions (get_nuts_geo(), get_nuts_geopolys(), get_nuts2_ref(), get_nuts2_names()) now cache results package-level environment instant repeated access within R session. clear_localintel_cache(): Exported function reset cache force fresh data fetches. Cascade functions now use cached get_nuts2_ref() instead duplicating geospatial fetch logic. Comprehensive unit tests utils, imputation, cascade, data processing, caching functions using mock data (Eurostat API calls required).

title: localintel 0.2.1
text: cascade_to_nuts2() cascade_to_nuts2_and_compute() now use cached get_nuts2_ref() function, avoiding redundant geospatial API calls. Added giscoR checks informative error messages functions depend geospatial data.

title: localintel 0.2.0
text: interp_pchip_flag(): PCHIP (Piecewise Cubic Hermite Interpolating Polynomial) interpolation missing years within observed range. Uses monotone Hermite splines (Fritsch-Carlson method) preserve monotonicity handle non-linear patterns without overshooting — significant upgrade previous linear interpolation approach. forecast_autoregressive(): Exponential smoothing state space model (ETS) forecasting beyond observed data. Autoregressive design, automatically selects optimal smoothing parameters via AICc. Falls back Holt’s linear trend forecast package unavailable. impute_series(): Unified pipeline combining PCHIP interpolation (internal gaps) autoregressive forecasting (future periods). Returns complete series flags distinguishing observed (0), interpolated (1), forecasted (2) values.

title: localintel 0.2.0
text: Interpolation vs Forecasting: package now uses two distinct methods — PCHIP within-range imputation (curve respect existing data points) ETS beyond-range forecasting (autoregressive dynamics drive projection). separation reflects fundamentally different statistical requirements task. Graceful Degradation: forecast package placed Suggests rather Imports. unavailable, system falls back Holt’s linear trend extrapolation manually estimated smoothing parameters (α=0.3, β=0.1).

title: localintel 0.1.0
text: get_nuts2(): Fetch NUTS2 level data Eurostat get_nuts_level(): Fetch data NUTS level (0, 1, 2, 3) get_nuts_level_robust(): Fetch retry logic fetch_eurostat_batch(): Fetch multiple datasets Pre-defined code lists: health_system_codes(), causes_of_death_codes() get_nuts2_ref(): NUTS2 reference table parent codes get_nuts_geopolys(): Combined NUTS 0/1/2 geometries get_nuts2_names(): Region name lookup get_population_nuts2(): Population data cascade_to_nuts2_and_compute(): Full cascade indicator computation (DA, rLOS) cascade_to_nuts2_light(): Simple cascading pre-computed scores balance_panel(): Fill missing year-geo combinations Processing functions Eurostat datasets: process_beds(), process_physicians(), etc. merge_datasets(): Combine multiple datasets transform_and_score(): Apply transformations scale 0-100 compute_composite(): Calculate composite scores keep_eu27(): Filter EU27 countries safe_log10(), safe_log2(): Safe logarithm functions scale_0_100(): Min-max normalization interp_const_ends_flag(): Linear interpolation flags add_country_name(): Add country names NUTS codes build_display_sf(): Build SF best-level display lc_build_display_sf(): Version life course data grouping plot_best_by_country_level(): Create tmap visualizations build_multi_var_sf(): Combine multiple variables Tableau export_to_geojson(): GeoJSON export Tableau enrich_for_tableau(): Add metadata Tableau dashboards export_to_excel(): Excel export save_maps_to_pdf(): Multi-page PDF maps
